citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
There is no vaccine history for an adult female nilgai that was euthanized on 30 August 2024 due to acute lameness in
the right rear limb that did not respond to treatment. No necropsy or diagnostics were conducted to determine cause of
illness, and the cause remains unknown. The program of veterinary care lists required vaccines for never vaccinated
antelope species to include tetanus, clostridium and rabies. Failure to follow the written program of veterinary care may
result in disease or death of animals. The facility shall assure that the attending veterinarian has appropriate authority to
ensure the provision of adequate veterinary care and to oversee the adequacy of other aspects of animal care and use.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
On a few occasions, the facility used expired anesthetic drug labeled "BAM" (butorphanol tartrate, azaperone, and
medetomidine HCl) to sedate animals for procedures. On 05 June 2024, the facility used BAM that had expired on 18
February 2024 on a common eland and a sable antelope. Then, on 30 August 2024, the facility used BAM that had
expired on 03 August 2024 to sedate a nilgai for euthanasia. The use of expired medical products is not an appropriate
method to control disease and injury in animals. For the health and well-being of the animals, each exhibitor shall
establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the use of appropriate methods to prevent,
control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant. All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 30 September 2024 or the applicant will forfeit
the license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License
Inspection. Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.40(a)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
There is no vaccine history for an adult female nilgai that was euthanized on 30 August 2024 due to acute lameness in

2.40(b)(2)  Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).

February 2024 on a common eland and a sable antelope. Then, on 30 August 2024, the facility used BAM that had 
expired on 03 August 2024 to sedate a nilgai for euthanasia. The use of expired medical products is not an appropriate 
method to control disease and injury in animals. For the health and well-being of the animals, each exhibitor shall 
establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the use of appropriate methods to prevent, 
control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 30 September 2024 or the applicant will forfeit 
the license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License 
Inspection. Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
